parts.question_text: Express the given expression in the form \(a + b\sqrt{7}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.
parts.solution_text:
To express \(\frac{3(2 + \sqrt{7})}{5 - \sqrt{7}}\) in the form \(a + b\sqrt{7}\), we need to rationalize the denominator by multiplying both the numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator, which is \(5 + \sqrt{7}\).

\(\frac{3(2 + \sqrt{7})}{5 - \sqrt{7}} \times \frac{5 + \sqrt{7}}{5 + \sqrt{7}}\)

\(= \frac{3(2 + \sqrt{7})(5 + \sqrt{7})}{(5 - \sqrt{7})(5 + \sqrt{7})}\)

\(= \frac{3(10 + 2\sqrt{7} + 5\sqrt{7} + 7)}{25 - 7}\)

\(= \frac{3(17 + 7\sqrt{7})}{18}\)

\(= \frac{51 + 21\sqrt{7}}{18}\)

\(= \frac{51}{18} + \frac{21\sqrt{7}}{18}\)

\(= \frac{17}{6} + \frac{7\sqrt{7}}{6}\)

Thus, \(a = \frac{17}{6}\) and \(b = \frac{7}{6}\).
